item.title: Dick Gregory discusses American politics
item.description: This interview begins with a clip of one of Dick Gregory’s performances, where he talks about nonviolence and Native Americans. Studs Terkel introduces his guest as an observer, explaining that comedians are the best observers in society. Gregory offers extended analogies to communicate his views on a variety of topics, including the Vietnam War, race relations, segregation, human rights, and urban renewal. [The date is unclear, but it has to be after 1970, since the Kent State Shootings were mentioned].

item.title: Teacher Vivian Cadbury and Lane Technical High School students read and discuss "Cadbury Tales"
item.description: Discussing "Cadbury tales," about teacher Vivian Cadbury, with students from Lane Technical High School in Chicago..

item.title: Studs Terkel sits down with Sandra Cisneros to discuss her new book of poetry
item.description: Sandra Cisneros sits down with Studs Terkel and provides behind the scenes commentary on poems from her new book "My Wicked Wicked Ways." She provides an enlightening history to them. "Curtains," "Velorio," "Arturo Burro," "I Told Susan Reyna," "Traficante," "In a redneck bar down the street," The Poet Reflects on Her Solitary Fate," "His Story," "Letter to Ilona from the South of France," "New Year's Eve" have been removed due to copyright restrictions..
